title: As an autistic individual, what makes reading facial expressions difficult? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have come to believe it is a failure in working memory to relate facial expressions to actual emotional states, and to logically reason through emotional states to the level of reflexive understanding. Many people with Autism can recognize a frown, a smile, and many other facial expressions just like everyone else. I have never met someone with Autism who was completely oblivious to someone’s facial expressions with the sole exception of those who are intellectually disabled who have Autism. What the difference really is, I have identified, is being able to translate that facial expression into an emotion, and from that emotion be able to process that person directly through the lens of that emotion and change the behavior of themselves in response to that. That sounds like a mouthful, but it should make more sense by an example. C = Q/(Delta)T. This is the equation for heat capacity, Q signifying heat and delta T signifying change in temperature. c = C / m. This is the equation for specific heat capacity, where C is the heat capacity and m is the mass of the object in grams. Now you can memorize those equations and regurgitate them. But, let me say solve for Q using m, (delta)t, and c. If you are a Physics major, this should be point blank and obvious. For some of you, this may be a bit tougher. So, we will use algebra to solve this. C = mc mc = Q/(delta)T mc(delta)T = Q Knowing data does not mean you can interpret it correctly, interpreting data correctly does not mean you can rearrange the data correctly, and rearranging data correctly does not mean you can manipulate it correctly. But, let me give a easier to understand example that isn’t so mathematical. Take five friends who are all of equal height, equal speed, and equal motivation trying to become basketball players for their local high school team. Andrew knows all the names of the maneuvers that a basketball player would perform on the court. Billy knows all that and what those maneuvers actually entail. Cole knows all that and how to execute the maneuvers on the court and follow the plan. Dylan knows all that and how to form and execute contingencies if the original plan goes wrong. Eric knows all that and how to form and execute contingencies that work in the team’s favor if the original plan goes wrong. Who could get on the team? Who could get play time? Who is the most likely to become a professional player or a coach? Everyone but Andrew could get on the team. Knowing the maneuvers’ names does not mean you know what they entail. Cole, Dylan, and Eric all have shots of getting play time. Billy is highly unlikely to get play time because knowing the maneuvers and what they entail doesn’t mean he can actually interpret the maneuvers into actionable things to do. Eric is the only one who can become a professional player or a coach. Cole can’t because though he can complete the maneuvers, he can’t switch from a maneuver when he sees problems come from the maneuvers. Dylan can’t because even though he can make contingencies, he can’t create good contingencies. Though he can rearrange the maneuvers, it doesn’t mean he can rearrange them correctly. Eric is the only one who can become a professional player. Why? Because he knows exactly what the maneuvers are entirely, how to execute them, how to rearrange the maneuvers in the best manner possible, and how to correctly create contingencies when the maneuvers have to be rearranged into a good order. Replace that with trying to become good at reading facial expressions, and that holds almost entirely true. As to the biological reasoning as to what makes Autistic people less able to read facial expressions intrinsically than neurotypicals, that is a question for psychologists, neurologists, biologists, and chemists to solve in the future.

The answers from Peter and Essay are closest to my sense of what’s happening. This was a topic of conversation once with a clever neuro-typical friend who tends towards being instantly popular. His answer was completely useless as far as giving me something to try and reproduce, but it was useful in contrast. Imagine a game where you are focused on a smallish number (3–5) of common objects suddenly exposed and then re-covered. You then relay the most basic version of what you saw. Ball, cat, flux capacitor, quarter, something green. Five things, pretty simple. You don’t have to know the cat’s breed, the year of the quarter, or even what exactly the green thing was, you were 85% there (points for at least catching the color of the last item). My friend can’t describe the other person’s emotional state in detail, but in that instant he understands broadly what their face is communicating. My NT friend is clearly deranged, and between us, a tad simple minded… I mean, come on: Baseball, with blue stitching, including a logo with a brown hawk, and a red one for Coca-ColaMale, short hair, gray and black tabby, polydactyl, heavily whiskered, with yellow-green eyes, and a white solar panel.And so on…Mentally, the data points are recorded on a spreadsheet and I’ve begun analysis… Wait? Did you just flash different items?!? What were we doing again? Would you like to see my spreadsheet? My friend was naturally focused on just the relevant & required data points. He’s often not even seeing things I am, or his brain discards them as unimportant. I’m getting a lot more data, but don’t have a fast mechanism for zeroing in on what is important. I won’t retain it long term, but I’m much more likely to notice eye color, an unusual posture, body odor (gag), and hair between their eyebrows. Small facial details MIGHT be in my spreadsheet somewhere, but that body odor… Was their mother a yak? It’s basically the same when walking outside with the NTs I know. I’ll be able to cross streets, watch for cars, converse, notice a cat across the street, an ant swarm on the sidewalk, and a quarter. My NTs will most likely survive the trip, but miss the cat, ants, & loose change… So they have the upper hand NOW with their facial expression recognition, but if house cats, ants, & loose change ever become lethal to humans, I’ll get the last laugh.

I am actually pretty good at identifying expressions if given time and context. However, this is because my therapists and internet pictures taught me what each expression means and how to contort my face to match it. For NT people, this is a skill that is hardwired into the brain since infancy to insure that the mothers stays with the child (according to some evaluation video). Lets take the alphabet for example. From an early age the alphabet is systematically drilled into our heads. We are carefully taught each letter and then how to put them into words and finally define those words. After a few years of dedicated teaching we are taught how to create meaningful and emotional phrases and works with the words we got from the alphabet. Easy, right? No. That took years to learn, and people still need to pause and re-read passages from books with complex and dual meanings just to understand what is being expressed. People don’t do take classes on expressions since they are hard wired into the neuro-typical brain, while writing is an institutionalized method of communication that we must learn and carefully process even when we know it well. For me, and probably a lot of other autistic individuals, reading expressions is like reading a very complex book that has multiple meanings that must be sorted and derived through context, but there’s a catch; we never were taught the alphabet behind the words that categorize different expressions. I know that a furrowed brow is either confusion, concentration, or anger/vexation. Now I need to look for clues on which emotion is being portrayed and then find where that emotion is being directed. Then I need to choose a response to carry out such as supplication or earnest clarification (depending on who I’m interacting with). This process has to be used for lip contortion, eye contortion, changes in complexion, shifts in stance, and a whole conglomeration of other ques that I must interpret and act upon to hold a conversation.

Thanks for the A2A. I think there’s a couple of reasons for me. Firstly, it’s not natural or instinctive for me to look at peoples’ eyes, or even their faces. If I’m looking at a face it’s usually because I’m lip-reading to help supplement auditory processing difficulties or I’m trying hard to “mask” (which I rarely do these days, it’s too exhausting). Subsequently, I take cues more from the mouth area and the eyes are a blank void as far as expression goes. Secondly, I don’t generalise. So I can learn to read one person extremely well if I apply myself, to the point that the person can never hide anything from me because my pattern recognition radar starts pinging urgently if something about them is different. It doesn’t mean I know what the difference is, and I will ask until they tell me because I can’t stand the dissonance. Everyone is a new and unique map of emotional markers and many people fake their outward emotions. If I don’t shut people out of my attention, I end up with a confusing signal to noise ratio as my brain takes in contradictory messages and it’s both exhausting and causes massive anxiety in me. Anyone I let close learns really quickly to stop doing it because it will provoke meltdowns. It’s unnerving for people initially because they have to be open and vulnerable with me - I know this because a few friends have told me so. So I can learn, but it’s hard and it’s not intuitive and takes a lot of mental energy. It’s like people reading animal body language - not intuitive and they miss subtle but important cues constantly. So many people have dogs but if everyone could read them properly, dog behaviourists would be out of a job. Instead, dogs are constantly being misinterpreted, treated poorly, discarded, put down etc because the people around them can’t read their nuances and communicate clearly with them.

The problem is the face just does not communicate any information to the person. He looks at the person’s face and simply draws no information from it, which gives him a very uneasy, anxious feeling. The brain almost always ‘feels anxious’ when it can’t understand something. That’s how we are all wired. This is a common problem in several different disorders including Autism and Schizophrenia. But it is by no means universal with all people with Autism. Many people with Autism have no problem looking at people. And when a person with severe Autism is really withdrawn, and starts to feel comfortable with you, very often the person will spend hours looking very carefully at your face, touching your face, touching your mouth, chin and features, often looking rather puzzled but curious, lifting and moving your hands, all with rapt attention and no unease about looking at your face. My thought on that is that once the person is familiar with your facial features and has studied them carefully, the person feels much more comfortable with you. With people with severe Autism, for many years there was a big emphasis on teaching them to look at people. The reason was that people often cited that as a source of anger and frustration at the person, so we wanted to avoid that anger bubbling up. Not looking at people was just a huge source of frustration for caregivers as well as people encountered in the community. Reactions were ‘he doesn’t love me,’ ‘he doesn’t respect me,’ ‘he refuses to listen when I tell him to do something,’ etc. So it helps when asking the person to do something that you know they are focused on what you’re asking, plus it helps with making the person more acceptable in the community - people just really do not like it when someone doesn’t look at them. As a result many severely Autistic people were trained to look at people by giving the Autistic person a reward such as a piece of cookie or candy when you said, ‘Look at me.’ I believe that helped people overcome their anxiety of looking at peoples’ faces. There’s nothing like munching on a cookie to help forget one’s anxiety (that’s probably why I’m so fat…..). The extremely funny result was that if the Autistic person wanted something, he would walk up to someone, reach up and put his hands on either side of the person’s face, turn the person’s head toward him and say, ‘Good looking,’ which created some misunderstandings…. My friend with severe Autism would often do that when he was asking a person something and the person was not paying attention to him. He did not understand the concept of not interrupting a person who was having a conversation with someone else. So as a result you’d be talking to someone, he would come up, gently turn your head toward him and start talking to you. I was struck by how little people understood of how my friend’s brain worked. But it definitely helped him get along in the world in general, that he could look at people.

Thank you for the A2A. It's hard to know. I was only diagnosed last year and only recently (like, in the last month or so) did I realise that I don't actually make eye contact if I can help it and not for very long. So, as I've only just noticed, I don't have any insight as to why. I guess I assumed everyone did that. And I have been complimented on job interviews for making eye contact with everyone in the room and making everyone feel involved. Without making significant eye contact. Also, and this was news when I was diagnosed, it turns out that most people don't spend their lives analysing the behaviour and facial expressions of other people. Most people, therefore, cannot tell when an emotion does not match the facial expression or spot the subtle signs that people are not feeling what they say they are feeling with their words or what their facial expressions are supposed to represent. Equally, most people don't get freaked out by the dissonance and often take people at 'face value' without thinking about it. Most people know the guff about 90% of communication being non-verbal but miss anything outside the face and words and, the bit that really confuses me, often take the verbal communication as the full truth when it is *obvious* something else is going on! To me, it appears as though the vast majority of people strive for 'socially acceptable' interpretations of facial expressions. Ergo, it's not that I, as someone with ASD, can't read facial expressions it's that the vast majority of people, as being PNT, don't care to match them with, well, anything. It's a double blind. Also, there's a whole pantomime that people engage in with facial expressions so that people make what they assume is one face even though it doesn't match their, well, body language. It is intensely frustrating to accurately deduce someone's expressions and body language, be told you are wrong and be reprimanded for 'not getting it' only to discover, much further down the line, that you were right. And then, blow me, be told that being right made it *worse* both at the time and afterward when other PNTs who offered no such insight and often were hurtful get praised for 'doing the right thing'. I suspect I have moved from the focus of the question...

I was recently diagnosed as autistic. It’s very mild. In my case, the answer is that I don’t look. I don’t try to read facial expressions. It doesn’t come naturally to me AT ALL. I’m busy thinking about what is going on, what is being said, what my next move will be, and so on. It is a lot to take in. While I could learn (and have learned a lot in time), it is a lot to take in. It can be quite overwhelming. All that said, I have improved immensely. It was not until I was in my late 20s that I learned that people expect eye contact during conversations. I was SHOCKED. To me, that felt akin to saying that I’m expected to walk about in the nude and engage in extremely intimate acts even with people I barely know. In time (I’m now 42), I’ve practiced eye contact enough that it now happens somewhat automatically. As others will likely point out, some autistic people study humans enough to become exceptionally good at reading facial expressions and body language, so much so that they become extremely good psychologists and the like.

I don’t think anyone can answer that. It’s like asking, “as a normal muggle, what makes levitation difficult.” It’s just not within our brain structure. One theory that rings true for a lot of autistics is the “intense world” theory. We lack the filters that protect neurotypicals (NTs). These can include sensory filters against loud noises or smells, but also social filters like intensity or personal space or touching.  Does this look like an uncomfortable position to be in for the person on the right? If your social filters are down, you don’t need a drill sergeant to put you at this level of discomfort. It could be something that most NTs find normal, even engaging. Note that the poor guy isn’t making eye contact. Would you want to in this situation? If an autistic person is frequently at this level of discomfort in social situations, they’re almost never going to make eye contact. Since you’re autistic from birth, that means you won’t get the training in reading faces during the critical parts of development that NTs get, and so you’ll be bad at reading faces. That will stay true even if (like me) you figure out in your late teens that people seem to expect eye contact as part of social discourse and start forcing yourself to do it.

I want you to look at the two sets of marks below and tell me what’s different about them. Oh yeah, and you have less than a quarter of a second to do it, and then tell me what the difference means.   If you really think about it, what separates one expression from another are tiny differences. The only reason anybody can do it is because most people are hardwired specifically for that job. Autistic people aren’t wired in the same way, so they have trouble. Plus, even processing that can be difficult during social interaction. It’s uncomfortable for many autistic people to look at and focus on faces. It takes a certain amount of conscious effort read a face, and that’s just more things to think about while flying blind through the stormy realm of socialization. As some may put it, “I can pay attention to your face or pay attention to what you’re saying. Not both.” As a fun excercise, horses also use facial expression to communicate. The next time you’re around some horses, try to spot their different expressions. Then try to figure out what they mean. That’s a bit what it’s like for autistic people who haven’t had specific training in reading faces.

Micro-expressions. Non-verbal facial-emotional expressions are constantly changing while communicating with the same person. I have read Paul Ekmans Emotions Revealed book, but have never been good at detecting change of emotions and feelings felt by others. I have been known to completely mis-attribute why people suddenly seem frustrated, impatient, or if they actually seem irritated by something said during conversation. Context and situational awareness are important, but so is knowing what impact words or thoughts expressed have had on others. This is the bit I don't “get” from social cues, and assumed shared common differences.

It’s a hard problem. Of course you can do it with the neural equivalent of an ASIC, but you can solve just about any problem with the neural equivalent of an ASIC. I maintain a fairly accurate prediction of where the objects and people around me are going to move, and I can remap my prediction onto an imaginary world with different physics. That, too, is a computationally difficult task solved with a dedicated system rather than by repurposing a general system. If you’re trying to analyze facial expressions in software, as it were, it’s a computationally difficult problem. If you’re trying to do it in real time, of course you’ll make some mistakes, like you would if you were trying to convert every color you saw into RGB values. Further, faces are sort of intense, so if the situation is intense too or I’m tired, my default response is often to look away from people’s faces in order to decrease the amount of intensity I experience to a manageable level. Good luck interpreting the details of something you’re looking away from.

When they don’t portray how the person is feeling. I’m quite good at reading facial expressions generally, I’ve practised my entire life, but sometimes I get it so wrong. People who have an angry looking face whilst joking sarcastically usually throw me! Or if someone is telling me some bad news but their facial expression appears happy, sometimes things like that don’t make a lot of sense, especially in regards to how to respond.

I am new to this forum, so apologies if what i share is no longer relevant. What i find with a lack of episodic memory is the ability to compare present expressions with previous ones. If i have no basis for recollection, i am absent in comparison. I have semantic ability, but every face is not governed by semantics, they are mostly fed by episodes of relevance. “I can smile, but do i feel happiness?”
The absence of the connection between the amygdala in the two hemispheres of the brain limits/eliminates the ability to process emotional cues. In my case, it is a physical scar unrelated to the ASD.
We just can't read such things. That's part of our interpersonal lack of skills.
